tags: all sansa chapters are so good
summary: “…A monster,” she whispered, so tremulously she could scarcely hear her own voice. “Joffrey is a monster. He lied about the...
caption:
“…A monster,” she whispered, so tremulously she could scarcely hear her own voice. “Joffrey is a monster. He lied about the butcher’s boy and made Father kill my wolf. When I displease him, he has the Kingsguard beat me. He’s evil and cruel, my lady, it’s so. And the queen as well.”

Lady Olenna Tyrell and her granddaughter exchanged a look. “Ah,” said the old woman, “that’s a pity.”

-Sansa, ASOS

summary: Will Sansa's children take Stark as name or will her husband found a new house ?
question: Will Sansa's children take Stark as name or will her husband found a new house ?
answer:
It depends on who her husband ends up being.

I’m of the mind that the story will end with Jon and Sansa marrying, with Jon taking the Stark name. Thus, he ends the story as a Stark (which he always wanted to be), just in a manner he never would have thought of.

If Sansa ends up married to someone else, it’s always possible that her children will still have the name Stark. IIRC, there is precedent for that type of thing. However, it’s something that the Starks will have to negotiate with the family of the man she ends up marrying.

blog.name: stormcloudrising
blog.title: Storm Cloud Rising
blog.description: Theories and analysis of my favorite shows, books, life and anything of interest

summary: Sansa Stark, the Symbolic Sea Dragon
title: Sansa Stark, the Symbolic Sea Dragon
body:
In my essay on The Bear and the Maiden Fair, I theorized that while there are several fair maidens associated with bears in the story, it would likely turn out that this song ultimately pertains to Jon and Sansa and the ancient characters they represent.  In the article, I also discussed why the Tully sigil suggests that Sansa is a golden dragon that has yet to be awakened by comparing the mythical one from the story to the real world one of the same name, which just happens to be a red-scaled fish.  The name ‘dragon fish’ stems from their resemblance to the Chinese dragon.  Native to Southeast Asia, Asian arowanas (Scleropages formosus), inhabit blackwater rivers, slow-moving waters flowing through forested swamps and wetlands.  

There is of course a famous blackwater river in the story that Sansa looked down upon as it burned green fire after Tyrion used wildfire against Stannis’ fleet. It’s also upon the Blackwater that Sansa; the dragon fish departed Kings Landing on a ship called the Merling King, which seems most apropos.  This maybe one of the reasons George symbolically connected Sansa to dragons in her escape from Kings Landing by having the small folks tell the tale of the wolf with bat wings.  It also may explain the suggested double meaning of Shadrach tripping over a bag of dragons in the Vale.  He will trip over not just Jon but Sansa as well.

Since I discovered the tale of the golden dragon fish, I’ve been doing some additional research on sea dragons and last night I came across the book referenced in the image posted above in an article on National Geographic.  The golden dragon is on the endangered list and the interesting thing is that some of the characteristics of the fish and it’s position as the most coveted and expensive fish in the world as well as the fact that it held in captivity are echoed in Sansa’s storyline.  

Now, I’m absolutely not saying that The Dragon Behind the Glass was the inspiration for George when he created the Tully sigil and symbolically associated with the sea dragon.  It was only published last year and so that would be impossible.  However, I do think that he knew about the fish and its association with dragons and it plays a role in the symbolism he has assigned Sansa.  Where Dany is the fire dragon, Sansa represents her water counterpart, which makes perfect sense—at least to me.

tags: i know it was meant to be an empowering line
but it isn't true in the slightest
a song of ice and fire
summary: Sansa Stark worked hard to meet the expectations that were bestowed upon her. She had to develop a wide range of skills her...
body: Sansa Stark worked hard to meet the expectations that were bestowed upon her. She had to develop a wide range of skills her whole life and remember a ridiculously long list of names (heraldry, major/minor families, people in power, etc), and be the perfect lady. These were all things her parents wanted her to learn. But they never prepared her for the political side of things. She came in King’s Landing unprepared for a lot of the things that she was going to have to face. She had to learn and adapt on her own in order to survive, and she had to do it quick, which is why it didn’t make sense when the show-writers acted as if Sansa was a slow learner, because one of the reasons why she managed to survive was because she was able to quickly adapt to her new environment and learn new skills. It was even stated that she was able to be a proper lady at three years old, but yeah sure she’s such a slow learner.

It was even stated that she was able to be a proper lady at three years old, but yeah sure she’s such a slow learner.

blog.name: tluohsalohcin
blog.title: Justice for Jon Snow and Jaime Lannister
blog.description: Official member of the Sansa Stark Defense Squad. Certified Jonsa Trash. Also a Nick Hoult loyalist since 2011.

summary: Ok, GA wants D*ny to be the YMBQ and to cast down Cersei but, to be honest, Sansa has already taken down her most appreciated....
body:
Ok, GA wants D*ny to be the YMBQ and to cast down Cersei but, to be honest, Sansa has already taken down her most appreciated. Just telling the truth about Joffrey to Olenna, Sansa is indirectly responsible of the next chain of events:

  • Joffrey’s death.
  • Oberyn’s death (as Tyrion’s champion.)
  • Tywin’s death in hands of Tyrion.
  • Myrcella’s death (as vengeance for Oberyn’s death)
  • Jaime abandoning Cersei, looking for some honour serving Sansa.

Compared to all of this that already happened, the only thing D*ny can take from Cersei is the Iron Throne and some kingdoms. Sure, Cersei is power hungry, yet she won’t suffer that much that she already had suffered before if D*ny wins her quest.

In other way, if Sansa is the one to take from her the throne, it completes the prophecy and will be a punch in the face for Cersei. In the way she sees it, she kind of adopted Sansa, taught her some stuff, let her share with her children, dressed her, feed her, etc. It will feel like treason for her.

Sansa went under everyone’s radar and has accomplished a lot, and gained the trust of her people. Sansa is now, probably, the most powerful political player by now and she isn’t officially or self-proclaimed queen.

tags: not costumes but I mean for tagging convenience
summary: Hey there. I read your recent reblog regarding Sansa's hair. Thank you for that, I'm seriously tired of people paralleling...
question: Hey there. I read your recent reblog regarding Sansa's hair. Thank you for that, I'm seriously tired of people paralleling Sansa's S7 hairstyle only with Cersei. I wanted to know your thoughts on Sansa's hair when she meets LF in mole's town in 6.05.
answer:
Hi there!

I guess you were referring to this post. People really do overemphasise Sansa’s season 7 hairstyle’s connection Cersei. There’s a lot of other influences there, which are lacking in Cersei’s hairstyles and have more to do with Cat and Lyanna. 

But that’s a very interesting question considering the scene right before while she’s making a cloak and receives Littlefinger’s letter, she has her hair down with only small braids on her side - like many Westerosi girls wear. [Edit: It’s actually her childhood Northern hairstyle on a closer look]

And when she arrives to visit Littlefinger she has it tied up in a braid like Cat. 

While I did bring up that at the end of season 4 Sansa starts wearing a fish braid like Cat did at times in order to appeal to Littlefinger’s obsession with her mother to keep herself safe when she knows he would kill just about anyone else, it’s a lot more complicated here. 

One has to remember that through season 5 post-wedding Sansa wore her hair in that fish braid and it wasn’t to appeal to anyone else. It was about her drawing strength from her own mother as she keeps saying in the books “I must be strong like my lady mother”. When Sansa escapes from Winterfell and Brienne swears her fealty to her as she once did to Cat, she’s wearing that braid.

And when she reunites with Jon too, she’s wearing that braid. 

But once she reunites with Jon, she finally lets her hair loose. 

(source)

In fact her hair here has more in common with her Northern hairstyle in season 1, that Lyanna in her childhood wore as well. 

Wearing her hair like this is symbolic of the fact that she feels at home again after reuniting with Jon more than she felt when she went back to Winterfell alone. And her hair remains so until she receives Littlefinger’s letter asking her to meet him at Mole’s town.

Until this moment, Sansa was starting to feel safe because of Jon’s presence and felt free to express her opinions. But after she receives the letter, wearing that braid is part of armouring herself again. Not to merely appeal to his obsession but to steel herself. Her modest clothing that has echoes of Cat contrasts her revealing Eyrie dress. She is completely covered up. Neither is she wearing a dress that mimics Littlefinger. Her dress is like Catelyn’s but the colours are of House Stark. 

She goes with Brienne and even the direction of the scene is done such that Littlefinger is happy to see Sansa but Brienne enters after her and his face falls. He wasn’t expecting her to have taken Brienne’s protection because she rejected it once and her presence is a statement that Sansa isn’t dependent on his protection as she once was. 

It has far more in common with Cat in this 2x04 scene with Littlefinger. Anyway I’m going to always be bitter that the show never included the book scene of Sansa sneaking away to the godswood to meet Dontos with a knife in hand for self defence. 

Cat is far more on the offensive at first but then Littlefinger needles away at her weaknesses - first her wanting to get back her daughters and later by bringing her Ned’s bones. He does so by suggesting that she could barter Jaime for her daughters (when Arya isn’t even there). 

Unlike Cat, in 6x05 Sansa tries to hold her ground and keep her emotions except disdain at bay. But he does shake a vein there by reminding her that Jon isn’t her brother like Robb or Bran or Rickon; he’s her half-brother. One that she was never close to and one that her mother distrusted. He does so while reminding her that the lords of the Vale remain loyal to her and Blackfish, her mother’s uncle is someone she should look to. 

People that keep saying Sansa is “stupid” for constantly relying on Littlefinger after he betrays her, don’t consider he fools Cat after she starts doubting him too and with Sansa, who is far more dependent on a protector to keep her safe and someone he essentially groomed as an abuser, he preys off her fears that she is alone even more. She’s faced longterm abuse under different abusers but showwise, Littlefinger has been her abuser longer than anyone else. Unlike other abusers he also creates the impression that he cares about her in a way others can’t. So after being stripped away from so much trust of goodness in the world, in love or god, she believes this terrible “love” is probably the best she’ll ever get or that it’s all she deserves. 

He tries to alienate her from Jon (and practically everyone else) so she can only depend on him, as he did with Brienne before. And considering the journey that Sansa has been through, she’s been reminded time and again that she shouldn’t trust anyone and been called foolish for doing so. Thus, even after she finally meets another Stark at last, she has to wonder if she really can trust him. She trusted her aunt Lysa and she tried to kill her. Littlefinger reminds her of her worst insecurities: that she’s letting her guard down too much. He reminds her that she can’t go back to being that little girl again. Hence that line “No one can protect me. No one can protect anyone” later. While I don’t think she was right in doubting Jon, it’s understandable considering the journey she went through and the number of people who have exploited her or tried to harm her. 

She has moments when she wears her hair like her childhood Northern style after this. This is contextualised by her telling Brienne “Jon isn’t Tormund. Jon isn’t Davos or the Red Woman or Stannis for that matter. Jon is Jon. He’s my brother. He’ll keep me safe. I trust him.” and Brienne points out that if she does, then why she lie to him about Blackfish when she knows he’s not like the others. This scene shows that she wants to trust Jon, but Littlefinger hit a vein there and she’s scared of putting that amount of trust in him. 

So from this moment onwards until the end of the Battle of the Bastards, Sansa continues wearing her mother’s Tully braid as an armor that screams “back off” to everyone than her use of it at the end of season 4, where she was attempting to use Cersei’s and Margaery’s tactics of seducing the enemy to survive. However, as I’ve said before Cat herself has a number of hairstyles apart from braids, i.e. semi-tied hair or buns. The nods to Lyanna are far more subtle because Sansa never met her and her statue isn’t exactly very revealing of her appearance, but the elements that make their way into Sansa’s look shows her Northernness.  

She uses aspects of Catelyn and Lyanna at different points by merging them with some aspect of Cersei or Margaery because in a world where “when you play the game of thrones you win or you die” and being a woman is dangerous in itself, you have to look to the most manipulative kind. And Sansa isn’t a warrior nor does she have supernatural powers, all she has to rely on is her mind or her body. When relying on her body, as Cersei, Margaery and Littlefinger would, failed - she had no choice but to rely solely on her mind again but play devious or offensive. 

And when she is finally in a position of power and she has been snubbed in Stark status because of her forced marriages to enemies, she looks to toning down her Tully side while still trying to evoke Catelyn Stark, Lady of Winterfell, but also playing more cautiously like Cersei. She has to adapt and constantly change herself according to what the circumstances need her to be - but underneath it all, there is still that part of her that looks to her mother, her father and her childhood. A lot of the characters struggle with who they want to be and who they have to be to survive and Sansa is just one amongst all of them.  

The trouble is Sansa never really reveals what she wants at this point (”What is it that you want? What do you want that you do not have?”). She doesn’t want anyone to know because as Littlefinger says in the books “When you know what a man wants, you know how to move him”. Her unreadability is one of her strengths, but Littlefinger does know her insecurity that she used to trust too much and he exploits that at every turn. In the light of that ambiguity, people fill in the blanks as they wish, trying to twist a childish fantasy of wanting to be a queen by a handsome king’s side into her wanting power. What Sansa truly wanted once was love and she wanted children too. The queen part was out of her fairytale fantasy. 

But life made her harden up and distrust more than she should because she was constantly made to believe her dreams were stupid and she trusted too much in the goodness of people. She also learnt that the only way to protect herself when she was considered a valuable pawn would be through a position of power. This dilemma of what she wants, what she has to be and what she fears informs her arc. She isn’t as confident as she makes herself out to be. She constantly living in fear, which is carried over from years of living that way. People often forget that, either because they think the place where Sansa is at is supposed to be completely idealised or they think she was rotten all along. Neither is true. She’s a work in progress, not a finished product. 

Frankly, she doesn’t even think of any longterm desire except trying to stay alive. The real question is “Who is Sansa beyond her never-ending fear?” I don’t think she herself knows or remembers anymore. But as the story comes to a close, she will have to think about it. She might’ve had to use their tactics but she’s not Cersei or Littlefinger. They’re more of a cautionary tale to her anyway. She has to let people in again and trust them, trust that there are good people in the world and love doesn’t make someone completely weak.

[Edit: It’s actually her childhood Northern hairstyle on a closer look]

And when she arrives to visit Littlefinger she has it tied up in a braid like Cat. 

While I did bring up that at the end of season 4 Sansa starts wearing a fish braid like Cat did at times in order to appeal to Littlefinger’s obsession with her mother to keep herself safe when she knows he would kill just about anyone else, it’s a lot more complicated here.

It has far more in common with Cat in this 2x04 scene with Littlefinger. Anyway I’m going to always be bitter that the show never included the book scene of Sansa sneaking away to the godswood to meet Dontos with a knife in hand for self defence. 

Cat is far more on the offensive at first but then Littlefinger needles away at her weaknesses - first her wanting to get back her daughters and later by bringing her Ned’s bones. He does so by suggesting that she could barter Jaime for her daughters (when Arya isn’t even there). 

Unlike Cat, in 6x05 Sansa tries to hold her ground and keep her emotions except disdain at bay. But he does shake a vein there by reminding her that Jon isn’t her brother like Robb or Bran or Rickon; he’s her half-brother. One that she was never close to and one that her mother distrusted. He does so while reminding her that the lords of the Vale remain loyal to her and Blackfish, her mother’s uncle is someone she should look to. 

People that keep saying Sansa is “stupid” for constantly relying on Littlefinger after he betrays her, don’t consider he fools Cat after she starts doubting him too and with Sansa, who is far more dependent on a protector to keep her safe and someone he essentially groomed as an abuser, he preys off her fears that she is alone even more. She’s faced longterm abuse under different abusers but showwise, Littlefinger has been her abuser longer than anyone else. Unlike other abusers he also creates the impression that he cares about her in a way others can’t. So after being stripped away from so much trust of goodness in the world, in love or god, she believes this terrible “love” is probably the best she’ll ever get or that it’s all she deserves. 

He tries to alienate her from Jon (and practically everyone else) so she can only depend on him, as he did with Brienne before. And considering the journey that Sansa has been through, she’s been reminded time and again that she shouldn’t trust anyone and been called foolish for doing so. Thus, even after she finally meets another Stark at last, she has to wonder if she really can trust him. She trusted her aunt Lysa and she tried to kill her. Littlefinger reminds her of her worst insecurities: that she’s letting her guard down too much. He reminds her that she can’t go back to being that little girl again. Hence that line “No one can protect me. No one can protect anyone” later. While I don’t think she was right in doubting Jon, it’s understandable considering the journey she went through and the number of people who have exploited her or tried to harm her. 

She has moments when she wears her hair like her childhood Northern style after this. This is contextualised by her telling Brienne “Jon isn’t Tormund. Jon isn’t Davos or the Red Woman or Stannis for that matter. Jon is Jon. He’s my brother. He’ll keep me safe. I trust him.” and Brienne points out that if she does, then why she lie to him about Blackfish when she knows he’s not like the others. This scene shows that she wants to trust Jon, but Littlefinger hit a vein there and she’s scared of putting that amount of trust in him. 

So from this moment onwards until the end of the Battle of the Bastards, Sansa continues wearing her mother’s Tully braid as an armor that screams “back off” to everyone than her use of it at the end of season 4, where she was attempting to use Cersei’s and Margaery’s tactics of seducing the enemy to survive. However, as I’ve said before Cat herself has a number of hairstyles apart from braids, i.e. semi-tied hair or buns. The nods to Lyanna are far more subtle because Sansa never met her and her statue isn’t exactly very revealing of her appearance, but the elements that make their way into Sansa’s look shows her Northernness.  

She uses aspects of Catelyn and Lyanna at different points by merging them with some aspect of Cersei or Margaery because in a world where “when you play the game of thrones you win or you die” and being a woman is dangerous in itself, you have to look to the most manipulative kind. And Sansa isn’t a warrior nor does she have supernatural powers, all she has to rely on is her mind or her body. When relying on her body, as Cersei, Margaery and Littlefinger would, failed - she had no choice but to rely solely on her mind again but play devious or offensive. 

And when she is finally in a position of power and she has been snubbed in Stark status because of her forced marriages to enemies, she looks to toning down her Tully side while still trying to evoke Catelyn Stark, Lady of Winterfell, but also playing more cautiously like Cersei. She has to adapt and constantly change herself according to what the circumstances need her to be - but underneath it all, there is still that part of her that looks to her mother, her father and her childhood. A lot of the characters struggle with who they want to be and who they have to be to survive and Sansa is just one amongst all of them.  

The trouble is Sansa never really reveals what she wants at this point (”What is it that you want? What do you want that you do not have?”). She doesn’t want anyone to know because as Littlefinger says in the books “When you know what a man wants, you know how to move him”. Her unreadability is one of her strengths, but Littlefinger does know her insecurity that she used to trust too much and he exploits that at every turn. In the light of that ambiguity, people fill in the blanks as they wish, trying to twist a childish fantasy of wanting to be a queen by a handsome king’s side into her wanting power. What Sansa truly wanted once was love and she wanted children too. The queen part was out of her fairytale fantasy. 

But life made her harden up and distrust more than she should because she was constantly made to believe her dreams were stupid and she trusted too much in the goodness of people. She also learnt that the only way to protect herself when she was considered a valuable pawn would be through a position of power. This dilemma of what she wants, what she has to be and what she fears informs her arc. She isn’t as confident as she makes herself out to be. She constantly living in fear, which is carried over from years of living that way. People often forget that, either because they think the place where Sansa is at is supposed to be completely idealised or they think she was rotten all along. Neither is true. She’s a work in progress, not a finished product. 

Frankly, she doesn’t even think of any longterm desire except trying to stay alive. The real question is “Who is Sansa beyond her never-ending fear?” I don’t think she herself knows or remembers anymore. But as the story comes to a close, she will have to think about it. She might’ve had to use their tactics but she’s not Cersei or Littlefinger. They’re more of a cautionary tale to her anyway. She has to let people in again and trust them, trust that there are good people in the world and love doesn’t make someone completely weak.
trail.content_abstract:
Hi there!

I guess you were referring to this post. People really do overemphasise Sansa’s season 7 hairstyle’s connection Cersei. There’s a lot of other influences there, which are lacking in Cersei’s hairstyles and have more to do with Cat and Lyanna. 

But that’s a very interesting question considering the scene right before while she’s making a cloak and receives Littlefinger’s letter, she has her hair down with only small braids on her side - like many Westerosi girls wear. [Edit: It’s actually her childhood Northern hairstyle on a closer look]

And when she arrives to visit Littlefinger she has it tied up in a braid like Cat. 

While I did bring up that at the end of season 4 Sansa starts wearing a fish braid like Cat did at times in order to appeal to Littlefinger’s obsession with her mother to keep herself safe when she knows he would kill just about anyone else, it’s a lot more complicated here.

blog.description: I write (primarily) Game of Thrones fan fiction including Petyr x Sansa, Tywin x Marge, Stannis x Sansa, Tywin x Sansa, among others.

summary: Presenting... Hysterical Maester Petyr Baelish is Westerosi's 19th-century wunderkind and heavily sought-after physician for...
caption:
Presenting… Hysterical

Maester Petyr Baelish is Westerosi’s 19th-century wunderkind and heavily sought-after physician for that which ails the likes of Lady Sansa most dreadfully: that most perplexing of female afflictions, Hysteria.

Unfortunately for all concerned, the Maester’s getting a hand cramp.

>>> READ CHAPTER 1

Helloooo! It’s good to be back! And yes, the summary does sound somewhat like the Hugh Dancy movie that came out in 2011. It was one of those things where I thought, “I KNOW! I COULD WRITE ABOUT THIS!” and then someone else goes, “Eh. There’s a movie.” “Aw MAAAAN!”

I don’t get out much. 

If you do happen to enjoy this one, could you be a darling and reblog? Thank you!

Sansa: No, the - wait, what fire?

Arya: Oh forget it, this sounds...
body:
